PROGRESS NOTE
Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date: 2024-07-22       Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD

Chief Complaint: Follow-up HTN, DM, new symptom - shortness of breath

Subjective:
Pt returns for f/u. Reports new onset SOB with exertion over past 4-6 weeks. "I get
winded walking up a flight of stairs now." Also noticing some ankle swelling by end of day.
Denies chest pain, orthopnea, PND. No recent illness or fever. Sleep still disrupted -
now waking 3x nightly for nocturia. Mood has been down - "feeling stressed and tired
all the time." Admits hasn't been to gym in months. Diet remains poor.

Forgot to take morning meds twice this week.

Medications: Unchanged from prior visit

PROGRESS NOTE
Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date: 2024-07-22       Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD

Objective:
Vitals: BP 154/94, HR 82, RR 18, Temp 98.2F, Wt 248 lbs (+6 lbs), SpO2 96% RA
General: Appears fatigued, obese male
CV: RRR, S1 S2 normal, ?faint S3, no murmurs
Lungs: Few bibasilar crackles, no wheezes
Ext: 1+ pitting edema bilateral ankles
Neuro: A&Ox3

Labs from 7/15 reviewed:
- A1c: 7.6% (above goal)
- Fasting glucose: 148
- Cr: 1.3 (up from 1.1), eGFR 58
- LDL: 122
- BNP: 340 (new, elevated)

PROGRESS NOTE
Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date: 2024-07-22       Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD

Assessment/Plan:
1. New dyspnea on exertion with LE edema - concerning for possible early heart failure
   given risk factors and elevated BNP. Order echo, refer to cardiology for evaluation.
2. Hypertension - poorly controlled. BP consistently >140/90. Add amlodipine 5mg daily.
3. Type 2 diabetes - A1c 7.6%, not at goal. Increase metformin if tolerated.
4. Hyperlipidemia - LDL still above goal. Will defer statin change pending cardiology input.
5. Worsening renal function - Cr trending up, eGFR 58. Monitor closely. May need to
   adjust meds. Consider nephrology if continues to decline.
6. Weight gain - 6 lbs since March. Contributing to above issues. Strong counseling on
   diet and exercise.
7. Mood symptoms - reports feeling down, stressed. Screen PHQ-9 at next visit.

Urgent cardiology referral placed. RTC 2 weeks for BP check, sooner if worsening symptoms.

LABORATORY REPORT
Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Collection Date: 2024-10-25 08:15 AM (Fasting)
Ordering Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD
Performing Lab: Quest Diagnostics - Columbus

[LABORATORY INTERPRETATION - SUMMARY]
SIGNIFICANT CHANGES FROM PRIOR LABS (04/02/2024):

1. DECLINING RENAL FUNCTION: eGFR has dropped from 72 to 52 mL/min over 6 months.
   This represents Stage 3a CKD (moderate reduction). Creatinine increased from
   1.1 to 1.4. This decline warrants close monitoring and evaluation for causes.
   Differential includes diabetic nephropathy, cardiorenal syndrome (given elevated
   BNP), medication effects, or combination.

2. WORSENING DIABETES CONTROL: A1c increased from 7.4% to 7.8%. Patient not at goal.
   Medication adjustment or addition of second agent should be considered.

3. ELEVATED BNP (520): New finding. Strongly suggests heart failure. If not
   previously diagnosed, echocardiogram and cardiology evaluation recommended.

4. MICROALBUMINURIA: Albumin/creatinine ratio 80 mg/g indicates kidney damage,
   likely diabetic nephropathy. Combined with reduced eGFR, this is concerning
   for progressive diabetic kidney disease.

5. LIPIDS: LDL remains above goal (<70 mg/dL) for secondary prevention in patient
   with established cardiovascular disease.

6. POTASSIUM 4.9: Upper limit of normal. If patient is on ACE/ARB or spironolactone,
   monitor closely for hyperkalemia.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Nephrology referral for CKD evaluation and management
- Ensure cardiology has evaluated elevated BNP if not done
- Review diabetes medications - consider SGLT2 inhibitor for renal/cardiac protection
- Monitor potassium closely on current medications

CARDIOLOGY CONSULTATION

Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date of Service: 2024-08-20
Referring Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD (Primary Care)
Consulting Provider: Dr. Michael Torres, MD, FACC

[REASON FOR CONSULTATION]
Progressive dyspnea on exertion, lower extremity edema, elevated BNP. History of
CAD s/p PCI. Evaluate for heart failure.

[HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS]
Mr. Thompson is a 66-year-old gentleman with history of CAD status post LAD stent
placement in 2022, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and obesity who
presents for evaluation of progressive exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema
over the past 2-3 months.

Patient reports he first noticed getting "winded" going up stairs about 2-3 months
ago. This has progressively worsened - he now gets short of breath walking one block
on flat ground. He has to stop and rest frequently. He also noticed bilateral ankle
swelling that worsens throughout the day and improves overnight.

He reports orthopnea - needs 2 pillows to sleep comfortably. No paroxysmal nocturnal
dyspnea. No chest pain or palpitations. He has gained approximately 8-10 pounds over
the past 2 months. Notes increased fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance.

Denies fevers, chills, cough, or recent illness.

Remote smoking history - quit 15 years ago. Previously smoked 1 PPD x 20 years.

Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date of Service: 2024-08-20
Referring Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD (Primary Care)
Consulting Provider: Dr. Michael Torres, MD, FACC

[DIAGNOSTICS]
ECG (today):
- Normal sinus rhythm at 82 bpm
- Left ventricular hypertrophy by voltage criteria
- Non-specific ST-T wave changes in lateral leads
- No acute ischemic changes
- Q waves in V1-V2 (old, unchanged from prior)

Labs (from referring physician):
- BNP: 340 pg/mL (elevated)
- Cr: 1.3 (baseline 1.1)
- eGFR: 58

ECHOCARDIOGRAM (performed today):
- Left ventricular ejection fraction: 40% (reduced; prior echo 2022 showed EF 55%)
- Moderate concentric left ventricular hypertrophy
- Global hypokinesis with regional wall motion abnormality in LAD territory
- Left atrial enlargement (mild)
- Grade II diastolic dysfunction
- Mild mitral regurgitation
- Estimated PASP: 38 mmHg (mildly elevated)
- No pericardial effusion
- Patent LAD stent by color flow

CARDIOLOGY CONSULTATION

Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date of Service: 2024-08-20
Referring Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD (Primary Care)
Consulting Provider: Dr. Michael Torres, MD, FACC

[IMPRESSION]
1. NEW DIAGNOSIS: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)
   - EF 40%, down from 55% in 2022
   - Likely mixed etiology: ischemic cardiomyopathy from CAD plus hypertensive
     heart disease
   - NYHA Class II-III symptoms
   - ACC/AHA Stage C heart failure

2. Coronary artery disease, status post PCI
   - Stent appears patent on echo
   - However, given new HFrEF, will need stress testing to evaluate for
     progressive ischemia vs new lesions

3. Uncontrolled hypertension
   - Contributing to LV remodeling and HF
   - BP 142/88 today despite 2 agents

4. Type 2 diabetes mellitus - additional risk factor for cardiomyopathy

5. Obesity - contributing to symptoms and cardiac risk

CARDIOLOGY CONSULTATION

Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date of Service: 2024-08-20
Referring Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD (Primary Care)
Consulting Provider: Dr. Michael Torres, MD, FACC

[RECOMMENDATIONS]
1. INITIATE GUIDELINE-DIRECTED MEDICAL THERAPY (GDMT) FOR HFrEF:
   a. Start Carvedilol 6.25 mg twice daily, titrate to target dose as tolerated
      (will replace need for amlodipine for BP)
   b. Start Spironolactone 25 mg daily (check potassium and creatinine in 1 week)
   c. Increase Furosemide to 40 mg daily for volume management
   d. Continue Lisinopril (ACE inhibitor is part of GDMT)

2. STOP Amlodipine - beta blocker will provide better mortality benefit

3. Consider adding SGLT2 inhibitor (empagliflozin or dapagliflozin) - benefits
   for HFrEF independent of diabetes. Coordinate with PCP for diabetes management. 4. LIFESTYLE MODIFICATIONS:
   - Strict sodium restriction <2 grams daily
   - Fluid restriction 1.5-2 liters daily
   - Daily weight monitoring - call if gain >3 lbs in one day or >5 lbs in one week
   - Smoking cessation if not already achieved (confirmed quit 15 years ago)
   - Cardiac rehabilitation referral

5. ORDER: Nuclear stress test (pharmacologic given deconditioning) to evaluate
   for progressive CAD. If positive, will need cardiac catheterization. 6. DEVICE EVALUATION: If EF remains <=35% on repeat echo after 3 months of GDMT,
   patient may be candidate for ICD for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death. 7. FOLLOW-UP:
   - Return to cardiology in 4 weeks for medication titration
   - Repeat echocardiogram in 3 months
   - Labs (BMP, BNP) in 1 week to check potassium/creatinine on new medications

8. COMMUNICATION: Discussed diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment plan with patient
   at length. He understands heart failure is a serious chronic condition that will
   require lifelong management and medication compliance. He expressed concern given
   his father's cardiac history.

CARDIOLOGY CONSULTATION

Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date of Service: 2024-08-20
Referring Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD (Primary Care)
Consulting Provider: Dr. Michael Torres, MD, FACC

He understands heart failure is a serious chronic condition that will
   require lifelong management and medication compliance. He expressed concern given
   his father's cardiac history. I reassured him that with modern treatment, outcomes
   have improved significantly. He is motivated to make lifestyle changes. Wife was
   present and will help with diet modifications and medication reminders. Patient was given my office number and instructions to call or go to ED if
   experiencing worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, or rapid weight gain. ================================================================================

PROGRESS NOTE
Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date: 2024-11-08       Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD

Chief Complaint: Follow-up after cardiology evaluation

Subjective:
Pt here for follow-up after seeing cardiology in August. Reports he was started on new
medications by Dr. Torres including carvedilol and spironolactone. Furosemide was
increased. States SOB has improved "maybe 50%" - can now do stairs without stopping but
still gets winded. Edema much better. Denies CP. Reports he has been "trying harder"
with diet - less fast food, watching salt. Still not exercising regularly.

Also mentions he's been feeling "down" and "not like himself" for several months now.
Trouble concentrating at work. Sleep still poor. "I just don't have energy for anything."

Current Medications per pt (needs reconciliation):
- Lisinopril 20mg daily
- Metformin 1000mg BID
- Atorvastatin 40mg QHS
- ASA 81mg daily
- Clopidogrel 75mg daily
- Carvedilol 12.5mg BID (new per cardiology)
- Spironolactone 25mg daily (new per cardiology)
- Furosemide 40mg daily (increased per cardiology)
- Amlodipine 5mg daily

PROGRESS NOTE
Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date: 2024-11-08       Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD

Objective:
Vitals: BP 132/82, HR 68, RR 16, Temp 98.0F, Wt 240 lbs (-8 lbs from July), SpO2 97% RA
General: Appears tired but less fatigued than July visit
CV: RRR, rate controlled, S1 S2 present, no S3 today, no murmurs
Lungs: Clear bilaterally, no crackles
Ext: Trace edema bilateral ankles, improved
Affect: Flat, makes poor eye contact

Labs from 10/25:
- Cr: 1.4, eGFR 52 (declining)
- K: 4.9 (on spironolactone, will need to monitor)
- A1c: 7.8%
- BNP: 520 (still elevated but pt clinically improved)

Cardiology note reviewed - Echo showed EF 40%, diagnosis of HFrEF.

PROGRESS NOTE
Patient: Robert Thompson    DOB: 03/14/1958    MRN: 12345678
Date: 2024-11-08       Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD

Assessment/Plan:
1. Heart failure (HFrEF) - newly diagnosed per cardiology. Clinically improving on GDMT.
   Will continue carvedilol, spironolactone, furosemide as prescribed. Patient counseled
   on daily weights, sodium restriction, fluid limitation.
2. Hypertension - MUCH better controlled today on current regimen! Continue.
3. Type 2 diabetes - A1c 7.8%, worsening. Increase metformin to 1000mg BID if tolerating.
   Consider adding SGLT2 inhibitor which would also benefit HF.
4. Renal function declining - eGFR now 52, down from 72 one year ago. Likely combination
   of diabetic nephropathy and cardiorenal syndrome. Defer nephrology referral for now
   given recent HF diagnosis - reassess in 3 months.
5. CAD - stable, no angina. Continue DAPT.
6. Hyperlipidemia - defer statin intensification given multiple medication changes.
7. Mood/possible depression - significant symptoms reported. PHQ-9 today: 14 (moderate).
   Discussed options including counseling vs medication. Pt reluctant to add another pill.
   Will consider at next visit. Provided crisis line number just in case.

RTC 6-8 weeks. Sooner if SOB worsens, weight gain >3lbs/day or 5lbs/week.

   to assess compliance, efficacy, and symptom improvement.

[LABORATORY INTERPRETATION - SUMMARY]
SIGNIFICANT FINDINGS:

1. PROGRESSIVE CKD: eGFR has declined from 42 (Stage 3a) to 35 (Stage 3b) over
   the past 8 months. This represents continued loss of renal function.
   - CKD staging should be updated from Stage 3 to Stage 3b
   - Cause is likely multifactorial: diabetic nephropathy (given severe
     proteinuria), hypertensive nephrosclerosis
   - Nephrology referral recommended if not already established

2. SIGNIFICANT PROTEINURIA: ACR 201 mg/g represents macroalbuminuria (A3).
   This is a strong predictor of CKD progression and cardiovascular events.
   ACE-I or ARB therapy indicated (patient is on ARB).

3. METABOLIC ACIDOSIS: Low CO2 of 21 suggests metabolic acidosis, likely from
   CKD. May need bicarbonate supplementation.

4. HYPERKALEMIA: Potassium 5.1 is elevated, concerning in patient on ARB.
   Monitor closely. Dietary potassium restriction advised.

5. ANEMIA OF CKD: Hemoglobin 11.2 with low iron saturation suggests anemia of
   chronic kidney disease with possible functional iron deficiency. Consider
   iron supplementation and EPO if Hgb continues to decline.

6. WORSENING DIABETES: A1c 8.2% up from 7.6% six months ago. Patient may need
   insulin initiation. Caution with metformin dose given declining renal function
   (eGFR approaching threshold for dose reduction).

7. HYPOALBUMINEMIA: Low albumin 3.4 suggests either poor nutrition or protein
   losses (consistent with heavy proteinuria).

SIGNIFICANT FINDINGS:

1. NEW DIABETES DIAGNOSIS: Fasting glucose 186 mg/dL and HbA1c 7.4% meet
   diagnostic criteria for diabetes mellitus. Glucosuria on UA confirms
   hyperglycemia. This is a new diagnosis - patient has no prior documentation
   of diabetes.

2. ATHEROGENIC DYSLIPIDEMIA: Classic pattern seen with metabolic syndrome/diabetes:
   - Elevated LDL (148 mg/dL) - above goal
   - Low HDL (36 mg/dL) - below normal
   - Elevated triglycerides (250 mg/dL)
   This pattern significantly increases cardiovascular risk.

3. METABOLIC SYNDROME: Patient appears to meet criteria:
   - Elevated fasting glucose (>100 mg/dL)
   - Elevated triglycerides (>150 mg/dL)
   - Low HDL (<40 mg/dL in males)
   - Likely elevated waist circumference (BMI 33.7)
   - BP noted as elevated in clinic

4. TRACE PROTEINURIA: Early sign of possible diabetic nephropathy. Recommend
   formal microalbumin/creatinine ratio to quantify.

5. MILDLY ELEVATED ALT: May indicate non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD),
   common with metabolic syndrome/diabetes. Consider hepatic ultrasound if
   persistent.

6. NORMAL THYROID FUNCTION: TSH 2.1 is normal. Fatigue not due to thyroid.

7. VITAMIN B12 NORMAL: 385 pg/mL is within normal limits. Important baseline
   before starting metformin.
